reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2023
reviews.reviewText: There aren't enough books for children that deal with the genocide that the Nazis imposed. This book fantastically tells a tale of a brother and sister and they evade the Nazis in the Netherlands. They have a sister who has been taken and a father who helps the resistance. My 4th grader, who was pretty apprehensive about reading, flew through this, so it isn't just a good book for adults, but fantastic for children! History is important to know, to learn from, to take the good, and know the bad so we do not repeat it again.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Life Skills Exemplified
reviews.reviewText: From the very beginning, middle-grade readers will be pulled into this WW II adventure taking place in the Nazi-occupied Netherlands. Quick thinking, bravery, adaptability, self-reliance, and faith are all traits modeled by the young protagonists as they struggle to re-unite with family. Based on actual history of the times. For those who want to learn from history, this book shines. Also, highly recommended as a family read.D. P. Cornelius, historical fiction author

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good WWII fiction for young readers
reviews.reviewText: The book is a good read. Go into it knowing it is meant for tween readers and even adults can enjoy it. I think parents of young children could also use this book as a good discussion starter about history and how war affects children.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great WW2 Youth Suspense
reviews.reviewText: What a page turner! I bought this book because I met the author at a writer's conference and was impressed with his teaching. I loved the accuracy of the history and the way he kept the pace of suspense up page after page and chapter after chapter. This would be great for the classroom or a home school curriculum. The cover is beautiful and the love and concern the older brother has for protecting his sister is a strong and touching weave throughout the story. Surely, this will inspire young readers. I'm so glad I bought and read this book. I'm sharing it with others!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Couldn’t put it down!
reviews.reviewText: This book is definitely a must read! It tells the truth without being to graphic. It is a great book you can read with your children or grandchildren. You have to keep reading to find out what happens next. Well written and exciting.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2020
reviews.reviewText: I enjoy YA books and this one didn’t disappoint me. Fast paced story that hooked from the first page. The lead character, Dirk is only 13 and the weight of the world is on his shoulders as he escapes from the nazis and protects his little sister. I enjoyed the historical references regarding the Dutch resistance to the Nazis. If your son or grandson likes history he will like this book. The author did a splendid job.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2020
reviews.reviewText: This is an exciting look back at a time in history when life was hard for everyone–the period of the Hongerwinter, the Dutch famine of 1944-1945 during the time the Netherlands was occupied by Germany, at the end of World War II. I have to admit I did not know much about this part of the war before reading this book, and it has spurred my interest to learn more.Told from the points of view of Dirk, a 13-year-old boy who is trying to find his way to safety with his young sister, Anna, and his older sister Els, who is part of the Resistance and has been captured by the Gestapo, Hunter Winter, shares a snapshot of the dangers and difficulties that people were facing during this time. It’s written simply so a child could understand, but is full of suspense at the same time and kept this grandmother on the edge of her seat wondering how these children would be able to survive…. to the extent that I finished the book in one sitting.There is a Christian message throughout the book; not heavy-handed but enough to show where this family gets its strength. One of the many pieces of advice Dirk’s father had shared with him was “Keep your hopes up and your prayers strong,” and it definitely helped him as he struggled to keep his sister safe.I highly recommend this book to families with children 10 and up. It might be a little much for younger kids, but it’s important that our children learn about times like these so hopefully they’ll know enough to keep history from repeating itself. There are some violent moments, but this was a violent time, so to leave those elements out would have been doing the readers a disservice.The author has obviously put a lot of research into this time period and, until I reached the end of the book and discovered the characters were fictional, I would have sworn the author was telling a story torn out of his own family’s history–the characters were that real to me. Good job, sir.originally posted at long and short reviews

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Some of the harder things about World War II
reviews.reviewText: Author Rob Currie doesn't shy away from some of the hard facts about Nazi oppression in World War II, but he does frame them for middle graders. This suspenseful tale takes us on a journey with Dirk and Anna, ages 13 and 6, as they run off into the night in the Dutch countryside to try to escape the Gestapo. I think this is a terrific book for those who want our young people to know the dark side of recent history. Lest we forget!
